definitions: write or print a letter or word with an initial capital letter or entirely in capital letters
take advantage of a situation or opportunity to gain financial or other benefits
provide capital funding for a business venture or convert into capital
examples: Remember to capitalize the first word of every sentence
She capitalized all the proper nouns in her essay
The company capitalized on the growing demand for organic food
Smart investors capitalize on market downturns to buy stocks
The bank agreed to capitalize the new startup venture
They decided to capitalize the improvements rather than expense them

definitions: surrender or give up resistance especially on agreed conditions after negotiation
stop resisting and accept defeat or unwelcome demands after prolonged opposition
examples: The enemy forces capitulated after the siege lasted three months
The general refused to capitulate despite overwhelming odds against him
She finally capitulated to her children's demands for a pet
The board capitulated and approved the controversial merger proposal

definitions: overturn in the water so that the boat or ship turns bottom upward
examples: The small sailboat capsized in the strong winds yesterday
Several kayaks capsized when the storm hit the lake

definitions: enclose something in a capsule or small container for protection or preservation
express or present information in a highly condensed or summarized form
examples: The pharmaceutical company capsuled the medication for easier consumption
Scientists capsuled the samples to preserve them for future study
She capsuled the entire presentation into three key points
The report capsuled months of research into two pages

definitions: lead or command a team ship aircraft or other group as captain
be in charge of and take responsibility for leading a group or vessel
examples: She captained the soccer team to three consecutive championships
He captained the ship through dangerous waters successfully
Who will captain the expedition to the Arctic next year?
She captained several commercial flights before retiring early

definitions: provide a title or brief explanation for a picture illustration or article
examples: She carefully captioned each photo in the wedding album
The editor captioned the cartoon with a witty political comment

definitions: attract and hold the interest and attention of someone through charm or excellence
charm or enchant someone completely making them unable to think of anything else
examples: The speaker captivated the audience with her passionate delivery
The novel captivated readers with its intricate plot twists
He was captivated by her intelligence and wit immediately
The children were captivated by the magician's performance yesterday

definitions: take someone or something by force or stratagem especially in war
record accurately in words or images the essence or quality of something
succeed in attracting and holding something abstract like attention or market share
examples: Enemy forces captured the strategic hill after fierce fighting
The police captured the fugitive after a lengthy manhunt
The photographer captured the perfect sunset over the mountains
Her poem captures the melancholy of autumn beautifully
The new product captured thirty percent market share quickly
The movie captured the imagination of audiences worldwide

definitions: travel together in a group of vehicles or with pack animals for safety
examples: The families caravanned across the desert for three weeks
Tourists often caravan through national parks during summer vacation

definitions: ask for and check someone's identification card to verify age or identity
comb and clean wool or cotton fibers before spinning using a carding tool
examples: The bouncer carded everyone entering the nightclub last night
She was carded when buying wine at the grocery store
Workers carded the raw wool before sending it to spinning
She carded cotton fibers to prepare them for weaving

definitions: feel concern or interest about something or someone's welfare and wellbeing
look after and provide for the needs of someone or something
have a liking or preference for something often used in negative constructions
examples: She really cares about environmental conservation and climate change
Do you care what other people think about you?
She cared for her elderly mother for many years
Nurses care for patients twenty-four hours a day
I don't care for spicy food very much
Would you care for some tea or coffee?

definitions: move swiftly and in an uncontrolled way in a specified direction
examples: The car careered off the road into a ditch
The bicycle careered down the steep hill dangerously fast

definitions: make or draw an exaggerated portrait emphasizing distinctive features for comic effect
represent or portray someone or something in a simplified exaggerated way
examples: The artist caricatured politicians in the newspaper every Sunday
Street artists caricature tourists for tips in the plaza
The movie caricatured suburban life in the nineteen fifties
Critics said the book caricatured southern culture unfairly

definitions: sing Christmas carols or other songs joyfully especially in a group
examples: Children caroled door to door during the holiday season
The choir caroled beautifully at the midnight service yesterday

definitions: complain or find fault continually about trivial matters in an annoying way
examples: He constantly carps about the food in the cafeteria
Stop carping and try to be more positive please

definitions: make or repair wooden structures or objects as a skilled carpenter
examples: He carpentered custom cabinets for luxury homes professionally
She carpentered a beautiful deck for their backyard

definitions: cover a floor or area with carpet or a thick covering
reprimand someone severely for wrongdoing especially by someone in authority
examples: They carpeted the entire house with plush beige carpeting
The stairs were carpeted to reduce noise levels
The boss carpeted him for missing the important deadline
She was carpeted by the principal for breaking school rules

definitions: transport or move something while supporting its weight with hands arms or body
support the weight of something or bear a load without breaking
transmit or spread something such as disease sound or information from one place to another
win approval or secure the passage of a proposal motion or candidate
have something as a consequence result or penalty
examples: She carried the heavy boxes up three flights of stairs
The porter carried our luggage to the hotel room
This bridge can carry trucks weighing up to forty tons
The beam carries the weight of the entire roof structure
Mosquitoes carry malaria and other dangerous diseases to humans
Sound carries well across water on quiet nights
The motion carried by a vote of sixty to forty
The incumbent carried all but three states in the election
The crime carries a maximum sentence of five years
This decision carries serious implications for our future

definitions: transport something in a cart or wheeled vehicle for moving goods
carry or convey something or someone with effort often over a distance
examples: Workers carted supplies to the construction site all morning
Farmers carted their produce to the market before dawn
Parents carted their kids to soccer practice every Saturday
She carted all her belongings across town when moving

definitions: perform a sideways handspring with arms and legs extended like wheel spokes
examples: The gymnast cartwheeled across the mat during her routine
Children cartwheeled on the lawn during the summer picnic

definitions: cut hard material such as wood or stone to produce an object or design
cut slices from cooked meat especially for serving at a meal
create or achieve something through effort persistence and skill over time
examples: He carved a beautiful sculpture from a block of marble
She carved her initials into the tree trunk
Father always carves the turkey at Thanksgiving dinner
The chef expertly carved the roast beef for guests
She carved out a successful career in journalism
They carved a path through the dense jungle vegetation

definitions: pour downward rapidly and in large quantities like a waterfall
occur in a sequence of stages each triggered by the previous one
examples: Water cascaded over the cliff creating a beautiful waterfall
Her hair cascaded down her back in golden waves
The financial crisis cascaded through global markets rapidly
One server failure cascaded into a complete system outage

definitions: enclose or cover something in a case or protective covering
inspect or examine a place before carrying out a robbery or operation
examples: They cased the delicate instruments in foam before shipping
The jeweler cased the watch in a velvet box
The thieves cased the bank for weeks before attempting robbery
Detectives discovered the suspects had cased several houses

definitions: exchange a check or other financial instrument for money
obtain advantage or benefit from a situation or opportunity
examples: She cashed her paycheck at the bank yesterday afternoon
Can you cash this traveler's check for me please?
He cashed in on the housing boom before prices fell
Politicians often cash in on their fame after leaving office

definitions: throw something forcefully in a specified direction
shape metal or other material by pouring it into a mold
select actors for roles in a play film or show
cause light or shadow to appear on a surface or direct something outward
shed or discard something naturally such as skin or horns
examples: The fisherman cast his line into the river
She cast the dice across the gaming table
They cast bronze statues using the ancient lost-wax method
The foundry casts metal parts for industrial machinery
The director cast unknown actors in all leading roles
She was cast as the villain in the new thriller
The tree cast long shadows across the lawn
His behavior cast doubt on his honesty
Snakes cast their skin several times each year
Deer cast their antlers after mating season ends

definitions: make a special chess move involving the king and either rook
examples: He castled kingside to protect his king from attack
You cannot castle if your king has already moved

definitions: make a systematic list of items with descriptive details
classify and organize items or information into categories for reference
examples: The librarian cataloged all new books received this month
Scientists cataloged hundreds of new species in the rainforest
She carefully cataloged her stamp collection by country and year
The museum cataloged artifacts according to historical period

definitions: make a complete list of items systematically with descriptions
organize and classify items or information for easy reference
examples: The museum catalogued its entire collection last year
Researchers catalogued plant species in the protected area
She catalogued her recipes by ingredient and cooking time
The company catalogued customer complaints by type and frequency

definitions: cause or accelerate a reaction or change without being consumed
increase the rate of a chemical reaction using a catalyst
examples: The protests catalyzed major political reforms across the country
Her speech catalyzed a movement for social justice
Enzymes catalyze biochemical reactions in living organisms naturally
The platinum catalyst catalyzes the conversion of harmful gases

definitions: hurl or launch something with or as if with a catapult mechanism
move suddenly or be launched upward or forward with great force
examples: The siege engines catapulted stones at the castle walls
The explosion catapulted debris across the street
The movie catapulted her to international stardom overnight
Success catapulted the company into the Fortune 500

definitions: grasp or seize something that is moving through the air or escaping
capture or trap a person or animal especially after pursuit
become infected with an illness or disease through exposure
perceive hear or notice something briefly or with difficulty
reach or board transportation or attend an event before it departs or ends
examples: She caught the ball with one hand impressively
The goalkeeper caught the penalty kick saving the game
Police finally caught the escaped prisoner after three days
The spider caught a fly in its intricate web
He caught a cold from his coworkers last week
Many students caught the flu during exam period
I didn't catch your name at the party
Did you catch what she said about the deadline?
We need to hurry to catch the last train
Let's catch the early movie showing tonight

definitions: classify or arrange things into categories based on shared characteristics
assign someone or something to a particular class or group
examples: Scientists categorize animals by species genus and family
The library categorizes books by subject and reading level
Don't categorize people based on superficial characteristics please
The study categorized participants by age and income level

definitions: provide food and drink at a social event or gathering professionally
provide what is needed or desired especially to satisfy particular tastes
examples: They catered the wedding reception for two hundred guests
A local restaurant catered the corporate lunch meeting yesterday
The resort caters to families with young children specifically
This store caters to customers looking for organic products

definitions: deceive someone online by pretending to be someone else especially for romance
examples: She was catfished by someone using fake photos online
He catfished multiple women on dating apps for money

definitions: make something happen especially something unpleasant or undesirable
bring about or give rise to an action feeling or situation
examples: The storm caused extensive damage to coastal properties
Smoking causes lung cancer and other serious diseases
His comments caused controversy among party members immediately
The announcement caused excitement throughout the entire community

definitions: warn someone about potential danger or problems ahead
advise someone to be careful or prudent in their actions
examples: Police cautioned drivers about icy road conditions this morning
The doctor cautioned him about the surgery's risks
I caution you to think carefully before deciding
Experts caution against making hasty investment decisions

definitions: collapse inward or fall in from external pressure or weakness
yield or submit to pressure demands or persuasion after resistance
examples: The roof caved in under the weight of snow
The tunnel caved during the earthquake yesterday morning
Management finally caved to the union's demands for higher wages
She caved and let the children stay up late

definitions: make the harsh cry characteristic of crows ravens or similar birds
examples: Crows cawed loudly in the trees at dawn
The raven cawed ominously from the rooftop

definitions: come to an end or stop happening or existing
stop doing an activity or action often formally or permanently
examples: The rain ceased after three days of continuous downpour
All activity ceased when the announcement was made
The company ceased operations after bankruptcy was declared
Please cease making that annoying noise immediately

definitions: give up power or rights especially formally or under pressure
surrender or relinquish territory to another country or authority
examples: The king ceded power to the democratically elected parliament
She refused to cede control of the family business
Spain ceded Florida to the United States in 1819
The treaty required them to cede disputed territories

definitions: observe a notable occasion with festivities ceremonies or other observances
praise or honor someone or something publicly with admiration
perform a religious ceremony especially the Eucharist
examples: We celebrated her birthday with a surprise party
The whole country celebrates Independence Day every July
The documentary celebrates the achievements of women scientists
Let's celebrate our team's hard work and dedication
The priest celebrates mass every Sunday morning
They celebrated the wedding ceremony in a beautiful cathedral

definitions: bind or join things together using cement or similar adhesive substance
strengthen or establish a relationship agreement or position more firmly
fix something firmly in place or in someone's mind
examples: Workers cemented the bricks together to build the wall
They cemented the pipes to prevent any leaks
The treaty cemented peace between the two nations
This deal cements our partnership for years ahead
The experience cemented his decision to become a doctor
Victory cemented their position at the top of the league

definitions: suppress or delete parts of publications films or communications deemed objectionable
examine material officially and suppress unacceptable parts before public release
examples: The government censored news reports about the protests
They censored violent scenes from the movie before broadcast
Military officials censored soldiers' letters during the war
The board censors all content before publication

definitions: express severe disapproval or harsh criticism of someone or their actions
formally reprimand someone especially in an official or legislative capacity
examples: Critics censured the director for historical inaccuracies
The newspaper censured the politician's unethical behavior
Congress censured the senator for violating ethics rules
The board censured the CEO for financial misconduct

definitions: place something in or at the center or middle position
focus or concentrate attention activity or interest on something
examples: She centered the picture on the wall perfectly
Center the text on the page before printing
The discussion centered on climate change solutions
Her research centers around childhood development

definitions: concentrate power or control in a single central authority or location
bring activities or organizations under single centralized control
examples: The government centralized power in the federal capital
They centralized all data processing in one location
The company centralized its operations to reduce costs
The new system centralizes customer service functions

definitions: place something in or move it to the center position
focus concentrate or base activities or attention on something
examples: She centred the vase on the dining table
Centre the image before taking the photograph
The campaign centres on voter registration efforts
Their strategy centred around cost reduction

definitions: provide someone with an official certificate or document as proof
officially authorize or validate something with formal documentation
examples: The board certificated her as a qualified teacher
They certificated all graduates at the ceremony yesterday
The agency certificated the building as safe for occupancy
Inspectors certificated the equipment for industrial use

definitions: confirm formally or officially that something is true or correct
guarantee that something meets official requirements or standards
examples: The doctor certified that she was fit to work
I certify that this is a true copy
The inspector certified the building as earthquake-safe
They certified the product as organic

definitions: tease someone in a friendly good-natured way about something
separate grain from husks by winnowing or threshing
examples: His friends chaffed him about his new haircut
They chaffed each other constantly during practice
Farmers chaffed the wheat using traditional methods
Workers chaffed grain all day during harvest season
